abstract: The session on Friday could be definitive, most likely capped by a vote on whether to hear new witnesses and consider new evidence.
lead_paragraph: Friday’s session could be definitive, likely capped by a vote on whether to consider new witnesses and evidence. But after that vote, which Republicans are confident will be rejected, things in President Trump’s impeachment trial could become a little messy. Nicholas Fandos, a congressional correspondent for The New York Times, walked me through what to expect.
